Articles.Content:
Believe it or not this is in english!

![AnthonyRoll-second_roll_sample.jpg](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/00/AnthonyRoll-second_roll_sample.jpg)

[Some quick googling indicates that it is from 1540.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Roll) Quite aside from the problems presented by the limited resolution, [early modern English is sometimes problematic to read](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_Modern_English). Though apparently this is more of a list of ship names/classes?

> 
> [Some quick googling indicates that it is from 1540.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Roll) Quite aside from the problems presented by the limited resolution, [early modern English is sometimes problematic to read](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_Modern_English). Though apparently this is more of a list of ship names/classes?

The ship in the drawing is the Henry Grace ÃƒÂ  Dieu, I find it kinda strange how the language when spoken would be perfectly legible same with the writing without the fancy type.

BTW take a look at this (Circa 900's)

![f4c80dd052dc226097fb3dae0c5284a7.jpg](https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/f4/c8/0d/f4c80dd052dc226097fb3dae0c5284a7.jpg)

its a viking dragon ship.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-06T04:45:08Z" title="03/06/2015 04:45  AM" data-short="9 yr">March 6, 2015</time> by daniel l.**

> 
> Though apparently this is more of a list of ship names/classes?

No, it's a list of ship's inventory.

The headings in red appear to be: Gonnes of <something>, Gonnes of Iron, Gonnpowder, Schott of Iron, Schott of Stoen and Leade</something>

I can't make out much more. The resolution is a bit lacking, aside from the archaic script and spelling.

> 
> No, it's a list of ship's inventory.
> The headings in red appear to be: Gonnes of <something>, Gonnes of Iron, Gonnpowder, Schott of Iron, Schott of Stoen and Leade</something>
> 
> I can't make out much more. The resolution is a bit lacking, aside from the archaic script and spelling.

I cant make out much either.

> 
> No, it's a list of ship's inventory.
> The headings in red appear to be: Gonnes of <something>, Gonnes of Iron, Gonnpowder, Schott of Iron, Schott of Stoen and Leade</something>
> 
> I can't make out much more. The resolution is a bit lacking, aside from the archaic script and spelling.

"Gonnes" are [hand-cannons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hand_cannon). Indeed, an inventory, or list of who has what.

> 
> Gonnes of

I was thinking it was "Brasse".

> 
> I cant make out much either.

[http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Anthony_Roll/Second_roll](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Anthony_Roll/Second_roll)

Of course, you still have to decipher the archaic spelling and terminology.

> 
> "Gonnes" are hand-cannons.

Looks to be a bit more extensive, to include all cannons onboard.

> Of course, you still have to decipher the archaic spelling and terminology.

Kinda funny how even when the type is deciphered it is still hard to read, I read something from 1580 and it was perfectly readable.
